prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SDSS587741391573287017
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observation of the Green Pea galaxy SDSS587741391573287017 in order to map the gas, resolve its kinematics, and trace inflowing/outflow motions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim here to detect the CO(1-0) line in these systems, and as argued above we require ~20 km/s channels. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz ($\approx$3 \kms), which we will bin up to 20 km/s in post processing. This configuration gives us the flexibility to relax our binning for face on sources, or increase it for edge on ones to get higher sensitivity. We place one spectral window on 12CO, one on shock tracer CH3OH, one on outflow tracer HC3N, and another on the CN lines (but these do not drive our time estimate). We will use 4x spectral averaging for these windows in order to reduce the data rate, as these lines, if present, are expected to be weak. These windows can also be used to detect any continuum from these galaxies (and accurately remove it from our line observations).

As above, we have assumed that the flux will be only marginally resolved each channel (tracing the spider diagram of the velocity field) as these sources are small. We hence estimate the LAS should be ~2 in each channel, and as such we do not expect to resolve out flux.

We estimated the mass of molecular hydrogen in the Green Peas using the measured star formation rate (3.2 Msun/yr: from the SDSS spectrum) and inverting the Kennicutt-Schmidt relation. We estimate the peak CO flux assuming a Galactic XCO factor and a line width of 100 km/s. We assume that this flux will be unresolved in each channel, as the total size of these objects is not appreciably larger than our beam. Requiring a 3 sigma detection of this flux yields our requested RMS in each case.
As discussed in our science case, the aim of this proposal is to map the gas, resolve its kinematics, and trace inflowing/outflow motions. We hence estimate the time based upon 20 km/s channels, which will allow an accurate derivation of the gas kinematics. We retain the flexibility to rebin in post processing to obtain greater signal to noise on weak lines, or higher velocity resolution on bright regions.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We aim here to detect the CO(1-0) line in these systems, and as argued above we require ~20 km/s channels. We thus propose to use the 1875 MHz basebands, with a raw resolution of 976 kHz ($\approx$3 \kms), which we will bin up to 20 km/s in post processing. We estimated the mass of molecular hydrogen in the Green Peas using the measured star formation rate (3.5 Msun/yr: from the SDSS spectrum) and inverting the Kennicutt-Schmidt relation. We estimate the peak CO flux assuming a Galactic XCO factor and a line width of 100 km/s. We assume that this flux will be unresolved in each channel, as the total size of these objects is not appreciably larger than our beam. prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Green peas are a class of low mass, compact and strongly star-forming galaxies in the nearby Universe (z~0.2-0.3),which were recently discovered by the Galaxy Zoo citizen-science project. Their spectra are dominated by very strong emission lines, e.g. [OIII], giving a bright green appearance in SDSS images. While these systems are nearby, they are likely to be local analogues to high-z star forming galaxies. Green peas can therefore act as laboratories for studying star formation in the early Universe. However, it is unknown what drives their prodigious star formation rates and the processes which formed them. Are green peas clumpy discs or mergers? Are there outflows and are these consistent with AGN or purely star formation? How efficient is the star formation and does it follow the Schmidt-Kennicutt law? We have recently observed a subset of the green peas using the SWIFT IFU instrument. Here, we propose to observe 4 green peas in ALMA Band 3 to detect the CO(1-0) line and map in these systems. Combining SWIFT and ALMA data will enable us to answer the above questions offering a window into the processes that drove the rapid build up of stellar mass in the early Universe.
